title: Celebrate the rise of accessible design â€“ it benefits everyone
excerpt: Fashion is a vocabulary. Clothing communicates parts of who we are, what we are interested in and how we want to be seen. It reveals choices that we make â€“ but it also exposes lack of choice.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Fashion is a vocabulary. Clothing communicates parts of who we are, what we are interested in and how we want to be seen. It reveals choices that we make â€“ but it also exposes lack of choice.

I am a disabled woman; I have dwarfism. My disability and stature is obvious and often shapes a first interaction. Iâ€™ve learned to love scouring through rails of clothes in high street stores and charity shops, and taking the items for alterations to make sure they fit. I know that if there are patterns or embroidery near the shoulder or ankle of a garment, altering it wonâ€™t work. Iâ€™ve found that jeans and trousers have to be elasticated at the back so they go over my hips with ease and donâ€™t gape at the back. Iâ€™ve also learned that dresses and skirts should have an asymmetrical hemline to accommodate the curve in my spine. As Iâ€™ve got older, Iâ€™ve discovered that many of these alterations donâ€™t just work for me, but would also improve comfort, independence and dressing for most people. Accessible design is better design.

To show you what this looks like in action: I recently had the pleasure of attending a dinner to mark Jannik Sinnerâ€™s return to Wimbledon. Beforehand, I was nervous. I wanted to wear something that would instil confidence, be comfortable and allow me to move about with personality and dignity. I chose a blazer, cashmere jumper and black pants. During my time working in fashion, I had the privilege of building relationships with designers, and this jacket was custom-made by Gucci. The pocket is proportional and the buttons are deliberately placed to be mindful of my figure. The wool pants are also custom-made by Prada and close with a fastener and zip, rather than a button, to avoid dexterity issues, and the back of the waistband is elasticated. The jumper is from Johnstons of Elgin in Scotland â€“ their store is step-free and has rails at multiple levels. I chose it because it needed no alterations; the short-sleeve is midâ€‘length for me, and wearable throughout the year.

Iâ€™ve spent almost a decade working in the luxury fashion industry, because I want more choice, more representation and more respect for disabled customers â€“ and across the industry there is lots to celebrate.

skip past newsletter promotion

after newsletter promotion

The Victoria and Albert Museum currently has an exhibition called Design and Disability, curated by Natalie Kane, that shows the innovation in accessibility. ItÂ features the work of Victoria Jenkins, the disabled designer behind Unhidden, aÂ leading adaptive brand that will be part of this yearâ€™s official London Fashion Week.

Tommy Hilfiger has an adaptive collection, Liberare creates bras that close at the front rather than the back, Tilt Beauty has a line of products that allow you to put mascara on with greater ease, and Primark has increased representation in the in-store mannequins and begun to make their childrenswear range seam- and label-free for neurodivergent kids. But, we need to think of disabled people as more than customers.

In 2020, I founded Tilting the Lens, aÂ strategic accessibility consultancy that aims to create the conditions for disabled people to be successful. Weâ€™ve developed a scholarship for disabled designers with Parsons School of Design in New York, and weâ€™ve spent the past year undertaking research with more than 200 disabled people across the UK to develop a white paper on adaptive fashion, to improve understanding of the market and innovation opportunities. Weâ€™ve learned so much about making clothingÂ more inclusive, but also the need for stores and real estate, packing and delivery to be accessible, too. IÂ want disabled people to be valued consumers â€“ but for that to happen theyÂ also need to be decision-makers, leaders and trustees.

author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
The clothing company Shein said it has opened an internal investigation after its website briefly displayed a shirt listing featuring an image resembling Luigi Mangione, the man accused of killing Brian Thompson, the CEO of UnitedHealthcare, in New York last year.

The image appeared to show Mangione in a short-sleeved white shirt, and the top was reportedly priced at just under $10.

In a statement shared with various media outlets, the company said: â€œThe image in question was provided by a third-party vendor and was removed immediately upon discovery.â€

Exactly when and for how long the shirt was on sale is unclear, with Shein uploading thousands of products every day, but searches for â€œLuigi Mangione Sheinâ€ on Google spiked on Tuesday and the listing began circulating across social media.

An archived posting of the product description for the â€œMenâ€™s New Spring/Summer Short Sleeve Blue Ditsy Floral White Shirtâ€ shows the item was nearly sold out, with only one size left in stock.

Mangione, 27, was arrested last December and charged in connection with the fatal shooting of Thompson. In April, he pleaded not guilty to all federal counts, including murder and stalking, and awaits trial. Prosecutors have announced they will pursue the death penalty if he is found guilty.

After the killing, some people opposed to the US healthcare system framed Mangione as a folk hero, with some rallying outside the courthouse during his appearances and contributing thousands of dollars to Mangioneâ€™s defense fund. Others have condemned the glorifying of violence and vigilantism.

Some online retailers, including Etsy, saw a wave of merchandise using his name. Amazon said it had removed any such products from its site.

Shein, founded in China, has built its global reputation on inexpensive, fast-moving fashion trends that attract gen Zers and younger millennials. The company has also faced repeated criticism over labor practices, including allegations of forced labor that the company has denied, as well as scrutiny for its environmental footprint.

A spokesperson for Shein said: â€œWe have stringent standards for all listings on our platform. We are conducting a thorough investigation, strengthening our monitoring processes, and will take appropriate action against the vendor in line with our policies.â€

The latest incident comes as the EU justice commissioner, Michael McGrath, vowed to crack down on the sale of goods that break the law. He expressed shock at the dangers of some goods being sold by China-linked online marketplaces such as Shein and its main rival, Temu.

Shein said at the time that it was â€œfully committed to ensuring the products we offer are safe and compliantâ€, while Temu said it had a â€œsystem of seller vetting, proactive monitoring and responsive takedowns to prevent, detect and remove unsafe productsâ€.

Meanwhile, the UK is reviewing rules that allow goods worth less than Â£135 and sent direct to a buyer to enter the UK without paying customs duty. The US recently scrapped its version of the â€œde minimisâ€ rules, which allowed goods worth less than $800 and sent direct to American shoppers to escape customs duty and some checks.

Shein had hoped to list on the London Stock Exchange this year, valued at as much as Â£50bn ($67bn).

However, it is now thought to be pursuing a listing in Hong Kong after failing to win approval from Chinese authorities for a listing in the UK. British MPs and investors have also raised questions about conditions in the groupâ€™s supply chain.

title: Vogue names Chloe Malle as new head of US edition
excerpt: The biggest job in fashion has finally been filled.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
The biggest job in fashion has finally been filled.

Following news that Anna Wintour was stepping back as editor of American Vogue in July, CondÃ© Nast have appointed 39-year-old journalist and Vogue staffer Chloe Malle as head of editorial content at the American fashion magazine. Her role is effective immediately.

â€œFashion and media are both evolving at breakneck speed, and I am so thrilled, and awed, to be part of that,â€ said Malle in a statement. â€œI also feel incredibly fortunate to still have Anna just down the hall as my mentor.â€

One of the most powerful roles in the fashion industry, her appointment marks not just a new chapter for the magazine but for Wintour herself, who will stay on in her role as chief content officer for CondÃ© Nast and global editorial director for the magazine, allowing her to retain control of the magazine, while no longer being involved in the day to day. Wintour was present at the July couture shows and itâ€™s likely that both she and Malle will be present for next weekâ€™s New York fashion week, oversee the Met Gala and Vogue World events. But in a first for the most famous magazine in the world, Vogue no longer has an editor-in-chief.

â€œAt a moment of change both within fashion and outside it, Vogue must continue to be both the standard-bearer and the boundary-pushing leader,â€ said Wintour. â€œChloe has proven often that she can find the balance between American Vogueâ€™s long, singular history and its future on the front lines of the new. I am so excited to continue working with her, as her mentor but also as her student, while she leads us and our audiences where weâ€™ve never been before.â€

Malle was editor of Vogue.com and co-host of the podcast The Run-Through with Vogue, and is a longtime Wintour insider, having been at the magazine since 2011. Responsible for editor-led newsletters, and successful annual â€œwittyâ€ tentpoles such as Dogue (a dog fashion magazine), she is more of a broad stroke journalist than a fashion insider. In 2014, she told Into the Gloss that she was â€œhesitant when I was interviewing, because fashion is not one of my main interests in life, and I wanted to be a writer more than an editor, but I was so seduced by the Vogue machine that I couldnâ€™t resistâ€.

Still, a frontrunner since Wintourâ€™s announcement, Malleâ€™s appointment will come as no surprise to anyone tracking CondÃ© Nastâ€™s revolving door. The former editor-in-chief is known for rewarding close deputies with international roles â€“ Mark Guiducci, Wintourâ€™s Vogueâ€™s creative editorial director, was recently helicoptered into the top job at Vanity Fair.

The gig was arguably up once Malle covered the high stakes and much-discussed Jeff Bezos-Lauren Sanchez wedding in Venice earlier this year. Given access to the bride before the ceremony and tasked with gathering additional details in the run-up to the wedding, the cover story followed her 2023 interview with the couple, and both are seen as proof of her mettle when juggling high profile celebrities with consumer interest.

A graduate of Brown University, Malle grew up in Los Angeles and began her career writing about property for the New York Observer. She has since written for the New York Times, Marie Claire, the Wall Street Journal and Architectural Digest. She joined Vogue in the features department 15 years ago, and has worked across various sections and platforms at the title.

Malle is also the daughter of American actor Candice Bergen, known for her wry humour and icy Nordic characters both on and off the stage, and the late film director Louis Malle, who lived in France because he â€œdidnâ€™t like living or working in Hollywoodâ€, according to a 2015 interview with Bergen in Dallas News. In another curious play between life and art, Bergen had a long-running cameo as the lovelorn editor of US Vogue in Sex and the City. Malle is also one of the few names to have had her birth reported on by People magazine.

Peter Ruis, the managing director of the staff-owned department store chain, said Topshop â€“ and Topman, which is to go into six outlets â€“ would â€œreally exemplify the new John Lewisâ€, as it tries to broaden its appeal with more fashion, home and beauty brands, ranging from Fenty to the Conran Shop.

He said Topshop was â€œa brand that is going to resonate with our gen Zs [those in their late teens and early 20s] and our gen Xers and everyone in betweenâ€.

Topshop, which launched in Sheffield in 1964, closed all its UK high street stores in 2021 after its parent company, Philip Greenâ€™s Arcadia, went into administration.

The brand was bought out by the online fashion seller Asos, which last week relaunched Topshopâ€™s website and opened an outlet in the London department store Liberty. At its height, Topshop had 300 stores in the UK and 11 in the US.

Ruis said gen X â€“ those in their 40s and 50s â€“ were more interested in fashion than their parents and â€œgrew up with Topshopâ€ and now had the money to buy it, while the younger generations were interested in 90s revival fashion.

â€œI think the best fashion brands are multigenerational. I think thatâ€™s always been the case,â€ he said, suggesting Topshop would â€œbring more of that family day outâ€ to the retailer. Ruis said younger customers were already shopping in its beauty halls alongside their parents and buying brands such as Mango but this would bring a new attraction.

He said Topshop would have a specially created area in stores staffed by handpicked John Lewis staff and was â€œgoing to have a lot of energyâ€.

Wilson added that Topshop had been â€œpretty open about the fact that we would like our own store presenceâ€ but there was â€œno defined datesâ€ for such a move and the brand was also not looking for other partners on UK high streets.

body:
Charli xcx is a British pop star known for pioneering trends. Last summer she turned the word â€œBratâ€ into a cultural phenomenon complete with a uniform featuring â€œa pack of cigs, a Bic lighter, and a strappy white top with no bra.â€

So it came as somewhat of a surprise to fans when, last weekend, she opted for a more classic bridal look to marry George Daniel, the drummer in the band the 1975.

Arriving at Hackney town hall in east London, the bride wore a white sculpted corseted minidress from Vivienne Westwood. Even her accessories veered towards the traditional: a bouquet of locally grown white cosmos and dahlias, a short white veil, and slingback heels.

Despite the look being more conventional than defiant, Alexandra Macon, the weddings editor of Vogue.com and founder of the e-commerce site Over The Moon, describes the pop starâ€™s choice of designer as a â€œperfect matchâ€.

â€œVivienne Westwood has forged a legacy as a true â€˜anti-brideâ€™ icon in the world of bridal fashion,â€ Macon said.

In 2008, Sex and the Cityâ€™s Carrie Bradshaw was jilted at the altar by Mr Big while wearing a floor-sweeping corseted gown from the British designer. Yet even without the coupleâ€™s eventual happy ending, a Westwood wedding dress has been desired by millennial brides ever since.

Seventeen years later, gen Z have welcomed their own bridal muse. This time the hemline may be shorter but the brand remains the same.

Charli xcxâ€™s dress was inspired by the Cocotte, a style of dress Westwood first unveiled in her autumn/winter 1995 collection. Featuring a swooping neckline, a waist-cinching corset and draping detail on the hip, the original paid homage to the dresses worn by the 17th-century French author and courtesan Ninon de lâ€™Enclos.

Westwood was one of the first to subvert the historical flat corset. Instead of lacing there are zip fastenings, and while the corset still moulds the body there are stretch panels for comfort. Since then, the brand has launched numerous iterations of the silhouette. Off-the-peg versions start from Â£3,200. The style is as popular among celebrities as it is with non-famous brides.

In 2005, Dita Von Teese wore a billowing purple version. Hailey Bieber wore a mini take on it for her nuptials, while Demi Lovato chose a longer length and added a cathedral-style veil. In June, the Hot Milk star Vicky Krieps wore a rose-patterned version for her Greek island wedding, while the model Daisy Lowe customised hers with a bustle and side slit.

Such is its ubiquity that last year Vogue declared it â€œthe wedding dress of the decadeâ€. Macon describes the silhouette as â€œinstantly recognisable and beloved, which is why we see it again and again on bridesâ€.

A finale bridal look has been the brandâ€™s show signature since the 1990s when the model Sara Stockbridge was an unconventional bride, carrying her baby down the catwalk in a dress depicting Jean-HonorÃ© Fragonardâ€™s 1797 painting The Swarm of Cupids.

Bridal is now a core part of the business with a dedicated atelier. In April, Vivienne Westwood staged its first standalone bridal show.

After trying on 120 dresses in her search for her perfect dress, the writer and influencer Katherine Ormerod was surprised to find herself choosing a Cocotte.

The Cocotte dress is also a hot ticket item on resale and rental platforms. Ormerod says that â€œin contrast to a sea of algorithmically fine-tuned brands and designsâ€, it â€œfeels like a bit of a FU to the lace and full trainâ€.

Six months after her wedding, Ormerod sold hers. â€œI canâ€™t think of anything sadder than that beautiful dress hanging, Miss Havisham-like, in a dust bag for ever. It wasnâ€™t a hard sell: within a fortnight it had found its new bride.â€

title: â€˜Rage baitâ€™ or good design? The Rowâ€™s Â£600 sliders are an exquisite provocation
excerpt: Rounded, cushioned and with a thick strap, foam sliders have been a familiar sight on feet this summer. While they are available for Â£30 from Adidas or Â£3.49 on the online marketplace Temu, a high-fashion version is now also on offer. The Ama sliders , in a choice of black, reâ€¦
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Rounded, cushioned and with a thick strap, foam sliders have been a familiar sight on feet this summer. While they are available for Â£30 from Adidas or Â£3.49 on the online marketplace Temu, a high-fashion version is now also on offer. The Ama sliders, in a choice of black, red or white, were launched by the American fashion brand The Row this week. They cost Â£600.

Laura Reilly, the writer of the influential fashion newsletter Magasin, called them â€œThe Rowâ€™s latest rage baitâ€, using the name for posts online designed to provoke anger, and go viral in the process.

Fashionâ€™s version of rage bait seems to be luxurious versions of everyday things. It remains unclear whether the creators of these items are deliberately provoking a reaction, but the prices certainly drive some consumers into a fury.

The Ama follows The Rowâ€™s other recent item in this tradition: the Dune sandal, otherwise known as flip-flops with a red sole, which cost Â£670 (they also come with a black sole, as worn by the actor Jonathan Bailey at an event to promote Jurassic World). But the brand is not alone. Items that have prompted similar outrage include a Loewe white vest for Â£325 and the Italian brand Golden Gooseâ€™s â€œdirty trainersâ€, which cost Â£435. Balenciaga, during the decade that Demna has been the creative director, has provided copious items here, from Â£720 Crocs, to a towel â€œskirtâ€ that cost Â£695 and a take on the Ikea Frakta bag for Â£1,365.

Dal Chodha, the pathway leader of Central Saint Martinsâ€™ fashion communication course, is familiar with the genre. â€œThis one in particular is brilliant because itâ€™s so well positioned for us to take offence, in the most exquisite way,â€ he says. â€œThereâ€™s an awful lot of [questions] that come out of looking at that shoe. The first is the one that most people ask themselves when they look at [a] work of art or any piece of luxury fashion: â€˜Why does that cost that much?â€™â€

Taking something ordinary and putting it into a different context has a tradition in the visual arts, one that Balenciagaâ€™s Demna is definitely influenced by. See Marcel Duchampâ€™s urinal in 1917, Jeff Koonsâ€™s 1980 vacuum cleaner and Martin Creedâ€™s light switch from 2000, all items that have prompted public rage.

But if art remains elitist due to the fact that most people canâ€™t buy it, everyone wears clothes, so consumers feel more invested when everyday items are sold for higher prices. This has long created a tension; Daniel Rodgers, the fashion news editor at Vogue, describes it as â€œan inverse form of snobbery from people who have always been cynical of luxury fashion anywayâ€ â€“ but it is exacerbated by online discourse. â€œEveryoneâ€™s voice is amplified so now weâ€™re hearing more from the people that donâ€™t get [items such as the Ama],â€ says Chodha.

The wider news cycle is also a factor. â€œIâ€™m interested in whoâ€™s defending that shoe, and is it defendable,â€ says Chodha. â€œI wouldâ€™ve been that person a while ago but now with all of the wars happening around the world and all of the economic struggles that weâ€™re all going through, I just think this is a bit insane.â€

Rodgers says the flatness of online exacerbates the reaction. â€œFashion is mediated mostly now through onscreen images,â€ he says. â€œIn the case of the Balenciaga Ikea shopping bag, you look at a picture of it on the screen and you think â€˜What? I can pick that up from Ikea for 75p!â€™, but what you donâ€™t see on screen is actually leather and it is actually made like a luxury item.â€

title: Escape Pod 932: The Walking Mirror of the Soul

author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Escape Pod 932: The Walking Mirror of the Soul

The Walking Mirror of the Soul

My desire was written all over Halcyonâ€™s torso, a shimmering tattoo composed of my thoughts and the Vonkraiâ€™s crusted skin.

{Tell VitÃ³ria you know.}

Luckily, we were alone in Teresa Stationâ€™s investigation room, so no one could read it. I was uneasy, palms sweating, tapping my feet on the floor. Normally, I met Vonkrai in restaurants, in the sightseeing deck or in the human-Vonkrai gatherings and conferences to restate our decade-long commercial and cultural partnership. In those places, their bodies were scrawled with everyoneâ€™s thoughts in a mess of unidentifiable and overlapping scribbles translated from human minds to Vonkrai bodies. Latin, Gujarati, Hangul, Cyrillic, Nsibidi, Arabic, and dozens of others from the Teresa Station human population. Mingled with our bulky and confusing thoughts, the Vonkraiâ€™s own dot-like script were scattered all over their bodies, words and logograms hopping from body to body, untraceable even for those who knew how to read Vonkraish.

But now, my mind glared back at me from their body like a damn accusation. It was hard to even follow the Detective 101 tips, like maintaining eye contact and interpreting body language. On the other hand, those things wouldnâ€™t really work with Vonkraiâ€”or they would be hard enough even for me, Isabela Cardoso, Teresa Stationâ€™s only investigator.

I tried to think about something else instead of my fiancÃ©eâ€”the case, think about the damn case youâ€™re being paid to solveâ€”so that those words were replaced, but they didnâ€™t shift. I shook my head and shifted my gaze from their body back to my comm-pad, skimming over the caseâ€™s file.

â€œHalcyon, can you repeat for the record what you saw in the market district?â€ Halcyon was my intervieweeâ€™s chosen Earth name. Each of them picked one for the health of our relationship, just as we picked aliases in their language.

â€œRepeating,â€ Halcyon said. I should be counting my blessings. Less than four percent of the Vonkrai had learned any of the Earthâ€™s languages, but Halcyon knew Portuguese. â€œA male human with a knife stabbed the victim, grabbed an object, ran.â€

I nodded, peeking at the picture of the dead man on my comm-pad. His mouth was puckered in revulsion, his eyes popped open in a frightened expression. JosÃ© Braga, a medical supplies vendor from Lorenzo Station who had recently acquired a stall in Teresa. Seemed like a simple case of robbery with homicide. Itâ€™d happened in the market district, where the off-station goods flowed in and out. And wherever there was money, there was greed; and where there was greed, there could be bodies. The only witness? Halcyon, who was crossing the district at the time to the quarters deck, where they spent half of each month.

â€œDid you say you were eating caldo verde at the time?â€ I said.

â€œAnswering: Yes.â€

I licked my lips. The environment module of Teresa was probably operating at lower levels of humidity. Or maybe I was getting nervous with the job (which wasnâ€™t common, but, hey, my fiancÃ©e had plans to move to Vladimir station and hadnâ€™t even told me about it, so I had the divine right of being overly sensitive).

â€œOkayâ€¦â€ I sighed. I peered into Halcyonâ€™s eyes, as if I could glean anything else from there. Nothing but the usual glint. Having evolved in the Goldilocks zone of their system, on a planet roughly the size of Earth with a similar atmosphere, the Vonkrai were like humans if you looked at them from a certain angle but extremely different if you looked from every other angle. They had our humanoid bodies as a distant resemblance, but theirs were rough like a stone and had a flinty periwinkle tonality, like an untouched vein of amethyst. Their eyes ranged from pitch to crystalline waters, their voices from whispers to drumbeats. Halcyon was a quiet one who spoke softly and hardly moved on the chair. If Halcyon were a human, Iâ€™d say they were extremely shy.

Notifications popped up in the corner of my padâ€™s screen. Twoâ€¦ Fiveâ€¦ Sevenâ€¦ Work time was work time, but only VitÃ³ria sent multiple messages in a row.

title: Escape Pod 931: The Rhythms of the World
excerpt: As always, weâ€™re starving to death.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Escape Pod 931: The Rhythms of the World

The Rhythms of the World

As always, weâ€™re starving to death.

From our place inside the leather pouch tied to Aamsaaâ€™s belt, our two remaining stalks ache with hunger, barely able to hold our withered green-spotted spore caps upright. We reach down with whatâ€™s left of our network of hyphal tendrils, hoping to lap up any remaining contaminants from the patch of poisoned soil Aamsaa found last week, but thereâ€™s nothing left. No scraps of heavy metals or drops of industrial toxins. Weâ€™ve consumed it all. And if Aamsaa doesnâ€™t find more food for us soon, weâ€™re as good as dead.

What can we say? Toxic pollution isnâ€™t as easy to come by as it once was.

â€œWhat do you think?â€ we puff a cloud of message spores up to Aamsaa. â€œAre we going to make it this time? Or are you finally going to let us die in peace?â€

The irregular cadence of her arthritic gait grinds to a halt, and she scoffs.

â€œYouâ€™re the all-knowing, century-old fungus. Why donâ€™t you tell me?â€ she says, and there is a smug yet endearing confidence in her voice. She doesnâ€™t speak her strange, breathy human language. No, she speaks ours, the Rhythms of the World, the language of the soil and the sea and the sky with its low susurrations of air and fine chemical exchanges. Her human vocal cords and oil secretions arenâ€™t designed for the task, but that hasnâ€™t prevented her from mastering the nuances of the Rhythms over the decades.

â€œWeâ€™re not all-knowing,â€ we say.

â€œThen quit acting like it.â€

â€œHilarious. Now about that food?â€

â€œDonâ€™t get your caps in a twist.â€

With her knobbly knuckles, Aamsaa unknots the pouchâ€™s drawstring, and we release a puff of sensory spores to take in the damp, writhing sea-top mess that is the floating city of Del.

The night is cool with sea breeze as we stand on a wide, kelp-woven street lined with biomaterial buildings that resemble overgrown birdâ€™s nests. At the end of the street, an ancient steel wind tower looms, its blades and turbine long locked by rust and streaked with slashes of peeling white tar. The cylindrical tower is massive; and its numerous window boxes practically vomit plant life, thick with diverse ferns and dangling ivy. A latticework of vines grows aggressively up the bottom half of the tower, covered in globe-like flowers that crackle with a soft teal light. And then, about halfway up, the vines grow outward in an almost mycorrhizal pattern, spreading chaotically overhead and latching onto the roofs of each birdâ€™s nest building, forming a gently glowing canopy for the hundreds of humans milling in the street below.

â€œItâ€™s beautiful,â€ we say.

â€œDelâ€™s famous for its phyto-engineering,â€ Aamsaa says. â€œThe people in that tower have innovated some pretty impressive stuff. Theyâ€™ve set up tidal turbines beneath the city and trained those LumiVines to store and conduct electrical charges. Itâ€™s an ingenious distribution system.â€

Clouds of moths, each individual as large as one of Aamsaaâ€™s hands, flutter around the LumiVines, their translucent wings catching and refracting the light. We watch them sipping sap, careful to avoid the electricity stored within the flowers. Every now and then, one accidentally nicks a charged stamen, but with a quick buzzing Rhythm of protection, the electricity discharges harmlessly from the mothâ€™s body with a soft teal pop. Hidden by the darkness above, we hear the wing beats of storm gulls surveying the scene, eyeing the moths for a meal.

â€œYou see?â€ we say to Aamsaa, â€œWe could die here. It would be a pleasure to join with these Rhythms.â€

â€œI hate to be the bearer of bad news, but youâ€™re not going to die today. Listen.â€

Beneath the creaking of the concrete floats and rusted wind turbines upon which this city was grown, we hear it: a piercing, droning, ragged whistling, like a kettle that has nearly boiled through its water. An inexplicable Break in the Rhythms of the World coming from a nearby alley.

title: Escape Pod 930: Fulfillment in Purpose
excerpt: Zima Blue episode of Love, Death & Robots
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Escape Pod 930: Fulfillment in Purpose

Show Notes

Zima Blue episode of Love, Death & Robots

Ezekielâ€™s speech from The Walking Dead Season 8 Episode 4: And Yet I Smile

Fulfillment in Purpose

Eland was resetting his motherâ€™s balancing sculptures when Hexben ran in from the storage room. The robot tilted its long head down while still making eye contact, managing a look of consternation despite its rigid, expressionless face.

â€œWhat?â€ Eland snapped.

â€œYou should be packing those into boxes,â€ Hexben said without inflection. â€œOur lease ends next week.â€

â€œExactly,â€ Eland said. â€œIt doesnâ€™t end today.â€

Hexben deepened the tilt of its head so far that its chin touched its chest in a spot where the paint was well-worn away.

â€œOne big sale could change everything,â€ Eland said, looking back at his work. â€œWe could renew the lease for six months with a single sale.â€

Apparently satisfied with that response, Hexben returned to the storage room.

Carefully, Eland stacked the thin wooden rods one on top of the other, following the notches his mother had carved, each notch designed to match only one otherâ€”â€œa kiss between sticks,â€ sheâ€™d called it.

Once heâ€™d used all the sticks, he was left with a one-meter-high stack on which he began to hang delicate glass ornaments in a carefully orchestrated patternâ€”the same pattern heâ€™d followed daily for three years. An obsession born of grief and repetition had burned the pattern into his mind.

He was placing the final ornament when the front door to the shop opened, letting in a gust of wind. Eland grasped the structure to give it support against the blast, but he pushed too hard and the entire thing toppled down to the table. The sturdy ornaments bounced, didnâ€™t break, but that didnâ€™t stop a fury from rising in Eland as he looked toward the door.

â€œHexben! I told you never to open that door when Iâ€™m in the middleâ€”â€

It wasnâ€™t Hexben.

In the doorway stood a figure draped in a heavy shawl with a rebreather masking its face.

Tourists, thought Eland, so frightened by the silt outside that they would purchase anything branded as safety gear, no matter the markup.

The automatic disdain passed, allowing Eland to understand what he was seeing: a tourist. In his motherâ€™s gallery. A customer.

â€œHello!â€ he said with a broad smile on his face. The figure turned toward him and mumbled into its rebreather.
